full_transcript:
[8.9s - 16.0s]: Hi friends, welcome to another edition of the Y Honors Communities Stewardship and Sustainability

[16.0s - 17.0s]: Podcast Series.

[17.5s - 19.4s]: I'm here with Brigitte Mars.

[20.3s - 20.9s]: Hi Brigitte.

[21.1s - 22.3s]: Hi, wonderful to be here.

[23.1s - 28.3s]: And it is such a joy to have this opportunity to visit with you today Brigitte.

[29.3s - 38.1s]: Brigitte is a teacher of herbal medicine and natural healing using the power of plants

[38.7s - 42.2s]: and has taught students all over the world.

[42.6s - 44.9s]: She has also written several books.

[45.4s - 46.2s]: 14 books.

[46.4s - 53.9s]: 14 books at this point, including the home reference to holistic health and healing, the

[53.9s - 61.5s]: natural first aid handbook, the country, Almanac of home remedies, the desktop guide to

[61.5s - 67.9s]: herbal medicine, beauty by nature, addiction free naturally, which is an amazing resource,

[68.6s - 75.8s]: the sexual herbal, also an amazing resource, healing herbal teas, rossum.

[75.9s - 82.8s]: I mean, it goes on and on Brigitte and this is, these are such a rich set of resources.

[82.8s - 87.5s]: Treasures really for us to learn from and I want to ask you something about the books

[87.5s - 88.2s]: in just a minute.

[88.2s - 95.4s]: But let me just finish by saying that you teach at Naropa University, the School of Health

[95.4s - 96.8s]: Mastery in Iceland.

[97.6s - 102.5s]: You've taught at the Omega Institute, S.A.L.A.N. and the Mayo Clinic.

[103.4s - 110.1s]: And Brigitte, of course, you're also a mother and a grandmother and it is such a joy and

[110.1s - 111.2s]: pleasure to be with you today.

[111.3s - 112.8s]: Thanks so much for being on our show.

[113.1s - 114.6s]: It's my pleasure and honor.

[114.8s - 115.3s]: Thank you.

[116.5s - 124.3s]: So I want to maybe start by asking, how did this all get started for you?

[124.5s - 126.4s]: I know that you've written all these books.

[126.7s - 129.1s]: You've taught so many hundreds, thousands of people.

[129.8s - 133.2s]: How did your connection with herbal medicine begin?

[134.3s - 139.6s]: Well, I was really blessed to have this French Canadian grandmother and she was very

[139.6s - 141.8s]: knowledgeable about the ways of healing with plants.

[142.5s - 147.1s]: And I would go visit her and it was almost like going back a hundred years in time because

[147.1s - 154.0s]: she had a root cellar and she made soap and a big cauldron in the yard and she had chickens

[154.0s - 154.5s]: in the yard.

[154.7s - 159.8s]: And her idea of ice cream was to put maple syrup, which we made out in the forest with

[159.8s - 162.9s]: these lumberjacks and then we would pour it on snow.

[163.1s - 164.9s]: And that was like hemglasse.

[165.9s - 173.1s]: And so by the time I was in high school, I knew that I wanted to study more about herbal medicine.

[173.4s - 177.6s]: I did not like getting shots as a child because I went to camp every summer.

[177.6s - 180.8s]: There was all these shots and it was very stressful to me.

[181.2s - 186.2s]: And I felt that the medicine that my grandmother was promoting, things like garlic and cabbage

[186.2s - 190.5s]: and apple cider vinegar, I felt like this is medicine for the people.

[191.2s - 195.0s]: And my parents would like, why do you want to do these old wives' tales?

[195.4s - 197.6s]: That's something poor people did in the old country.

[198.3s - 200.5s]: And I felt like, yeah, but it works.

[201.1s - 205.8s]: And it's good for the planet because every time we decide to use a natural medicine,

[206.4s - 211.5s]: somewhere on the planet there's going to be a field of cabbage or lavender or a canesia

[211.5s - 218.2s]: rather than a pharmaceutical company pumping smoke into the environment, not to say that

[218.2s - 219.7s]: those things can't be lifesaving.

[220.4s - 225.2s]: But when I was in high school, every time I had a paper to do, I would turn it into an

[225.2s - 226.7s]: opportunity to learn about herbs.

[227.2s - 234.6s]: So if it was Spanish, I would write about plantas medicinales, de Mexico, or herbal medicine

[234.6s - 235.9s]: during the French Revolution.

[237.3s - 241.8s]: And then I actually treated all my classmates rather than them going to the nurse.

[241.8s - 245.6s]: I had this drawer of rescue remedy and chamomile tea.

[246.2s - 249.3s]: I was just a kid, but I was experimenting on my friends and it worked.

[250.1s - 252.1s]: Of walking pharmacopia.

[252.5s - 253.0s]: I love it.

[253.3s - 258.3s]: And this is something that has been used by millions of people for thousands of years.

[258.6s - 263.7s]: So when someone tries to say, like, oh, herbal medicine hasn't really been tested, it's been

[263.7s - 267.2s]: tested a lot longer than a two-year rat study in my book.

[267.3s - 268.1s]: No doubt about that.

[268.3s - 273.9s]: For countless generations, one of the things that strikes me that I discussed a bit in

[273.9s - 278.6s]: the book, Why On Earth, toward the beginning, actually, is that we don't have to go back

[279.1s - 284.9s]: very many generations, regardless of who we are and where we happen to be living on the

[284.9s - 285.2s]: planet.

[285.2s - 292.8s]: We don't have to go back very many generations to find that in all of our ancestries, all

[292.8s - 298.8s]: of us shared, all of humanity, is a background in a past where we use herbal medicine.

[298.8s - 304.1s]: That was normal for so many hundreds and thousands of years.

[304.3s - 310.3s]: It is only in the last two or three generations where it is abnormal, where we have this

[310.3s - 314.9s]: aberration where, for many people, it's like herbal medicine, oh, what's that new fat

[314.9s - 317.0s]: or what's that strange fringe thing?

[317.2s - 319.5s]: But in fact, this is the norm.

[320.0s - 320.1s]: Right.

[320.2s - 321.9s]: There's nothing new age about it.

[322.1s - 322.8s]: It is ancient.

[322.8s - 328.4s]: In 1900, about 80% of all the pharmaceuticals were derived from plants.

[328.9s - 332.7s]: We had Willow Bark that came from Meadow, Sweden, and Aspen.

[334.8s - 338.0s]: We had birth control pills that were derived from wild yam.

[338.3s - 343.3s]: Even digitalis comes from the plant Foxglove, which is toxic to use as a plant.

[344.0s - 352.3s]: But in 1917, there was a movement where they sent one man, the flexner, Mr. Flexner.

[352.3s - 355.1s]: They sent him around to all the medical schools in the country.

[355.4s - 359.7s]: And he was supposed to make a deal with the medical schools that if they would only teach

[359.7s - 362.8s]: the new modern medicine, they would get funding.

[363.3s - 367.6s]: And if they persisted in teaching about herbs and homeopathy, they wouldn't get funding.

[367.8s - 373.6s]: So in a few years, herbal medicine really died on the vine, unless it was still being

[378.5s - 381.0s]: But in Europe, the herbs never got taken off the shelf.

[381.0s - 382.4s]: They've always coexisted.

[382.5s - 388.1s]: And I feel we're blessed because if you were in an accident, the modern care that the

[389.5s - 394.5s]: And I feel that the best of medicine is yet to come when we honor the natural remedies

[394.5s - 400.3s]: and put our heads and hearts together to also offer what technology is offering us.

[401.3s - 403.5s]: Yeah, that's such a beautiful, beautiful vision.

[403.5s - 410.9s]: You know, one of the things that I love sharing because like you, I'm busy working on new

[410.9s - 413.5s]: writing projects, giving talks, consulting.

[414.3s - 419.4s]: And I have found that in order to maintain a good level of sustained energy, health and

[419.4s - 424.8s]: well-being for myself, it's essential that I utilize some of the herbal medicines that

[424.8s - 425.3s]: are available.

[425.5s - 428.6s]: And I thought I'd bring some Brigitte for us to share together.

[428.6s - 432.1s]: So, this is a teason I made last night.

[433.0s - 441.4s]: And it has some beautiful organic and even biodynamic herbs including calendula, licorice

[457.0s - 460.1s]: That sounds wonderful and those are all really great herbs.

[460.5s - 461.8s]: So, I love it.

[462.0s - 464.2s]: You know, we're imbibing herbal teas.

[464.5s - 471.0s]: The plants transform the minerals of the earth into a way that we can readily assimilate

[471.0s - 471.3s]: them.

[472.2s - 473.0s]: So, my friend.

[473.1s - 473.9s]: My friend.

[474.1s - 474.7s]: To your house.

[475.1s - 475.8s]: Blessed be.

[476.2s - 476.7s]: Blessed be.

[481.7s - 482.3s]: Yum.

[482.7s - 483.3s]: Oh, it's wonderful.

[483.9s - 486.1s]: Liquid makes things just a little bit sweet.

[486.5s - 486.6s]: Yes.

[487.2s - 491.8s]: And one of the things I love about the licorice is because when I'm, you know, giving talks

[491.8s - 496.5s]: or what have you, my throat can get raspy and the licorice helps to soothe that a bit.

[502.9s - 508.0s]: Because I know that you have a few favorites in this whole farmacopia.

[572.0s - 576.8s]: And you know, you might have heard of stinging nettles and this is the same plant, Ertica

[578.3s - 580.3s]: It does sting you if you touch it.
